<!--[if lt IE 7]><style type="text/css">body{behavior:url("/w/skins/vector/csshover.min.htc")}</style><![endif]--></head>
<body class="mediawiki ltr sitedir-ltr ns-0 ns-subject page-Veganism skin-vector action-view vector-animateLayout">
		<div id="mw-page-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="mw-head-base" class="noprint"></div>
		<div id="content" class="mw-body" role="main">
			<a id="top"></a>
			<div id="mw-js-message" style="display:none;"></div>
						<h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en"><span dir="auto">Veganism</span></h1>
			<div id="bodyContent">
								<div id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
								<div id="contentSub"></div>
												<div id="jump-to-nav" class="mw-jump">
					Jump to:					<a href="#mw-navigation">navigation</a>, 					<a href="#p-search">search</a>
				</div>
				<div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr"><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Redirect6&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Redirect6 (page does not exist)">Template:Redirect6</a>
{{#invoke:Infobox|infobox}}
<b>Veganism</b> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a> is the practice of abstaining from the use of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_product&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal product (page does not exist)">animal products</a>, particularly in diet, as well as following an associated philosophy that rejects the <a href="/wiki/Commodity" title="Commodity">commodity</a> status of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sentiocentrism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sentiocentrism (page does not exist)">sentient</a> animals. A follower of veganism is known as a <b>vegan</b>.
</p><p>Distinctions are sometimes made between different categories of veganism. <b>Dietary vegans</b> (or strict <a href="/wiki/Vegetarianism" title="Vegetarianism">vegetarians</a>) refrain from consuming animal products, not only meat but, in contrast to <a href="/wiki/Ovo-lacto_vegetarianism" title="Ovo-lacto vegetarianism">ovo-lacto vegetarians</a>, also eggs, dairy products and other animal-derived substances. The term <b>ethical vegan</b> is often applied to those who not only follow a vegan diet, but extend the vegan philosophy into other areas of their lives, and oppose the use of animals or animal products for any purpose.<sup id="cite_ref-ethicaldietary_1-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ethicaldietary-1">[1]</a></sup> Another term used is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Environmental_vegetarianism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Environmental vegetarianism (page does not exist)">environmental veganism</a>, which refers to the avoidance of animal products on the premise that the harvesting or industrial farming of animals is environmentally damaging and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sustainability&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sustainability (page does not exist)">unsustainable</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-environmental_2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-environmental-2">[2]</a></sup>
</p><p>The term <i>vegan</i> was coined in 1944 by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Watson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Donald Watson (page does not exist)">Donald Watson</a> when he co-founded the British <a href="/wiki/Vegan_Society" title="Vegan Society">Vegan Society</a>, at first to mean "non-dairy vegetarian" and later to refer to "the doctrine that man should live without exploiting animals."<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> Interest in veganism increased in the 2000s; vegan food became increasingly available in supermarkets and restaurants in many countries, and several top athletes in endurance sports, such as the <a href="/wiki/Ironman_triathlon" title="Ironman triathlon" class="mw-redirect">Ironman triathlon</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Ultramarathon" title="Ultramarathon">ultramarathon</a>, began to practise veganism and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Raw_veganism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Raw veganism (page does not exist)">raw veganism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 2009 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Review_article&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Review article (page does not exist)">review</a> of recent research indicated that vegan diets tend to be higher in dietary fibre, magnesium, folic acid, vitamin C, vitamin E, iron and phytochemicals, and lower in calories, saturated fat, cholesterol, long-chain omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin D, calcium, zinc and vitamin B12.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> Well-planned vegan diets appear to offer protection against certain degenerative conditions, including heart disease,<sup id="cite_ref-disease_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-disease-6">[6]</a></sup> and as of 2013 were regarded as appropriate for all stages of the life-cycle by the American Dietetic Association, the Australian National Health and Medical Research Council, and Dietitians of Canada.<sup id="cite_ref-dietitians_7-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dietitians-7">[7]</a></sup> Because uncontaminated plant foods do not provide vitamin B12 (which is produced by <a href="/wiki/Microorganisms" title="Microorganisms" class="mw-redirect">microorganisms</a> such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacteria&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacteria (page does not exist)">bacteria</a>), <a href="#Vitamin_B12">researchers agree</a> that vegans should eat B12-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Food_fortification&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food fortification (page does not exist)">fortified</a> foods or take a supplement.<sup id="cite_ref-B12extra_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-B12extra-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

</li>

</div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coining_the_term_vegetarian">Coining the term <i>vegetarian</i></span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Fruitlands_in_1915.jpg" title="File:Fruitlands in 1915.jpg">File:Fruitlands in 1915.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Fruitlands_(transcendental_center)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fruitlands (transcendental center) (page does not exist)">Fruitlands</a> in 1915, an early vegan community in Harvard, Massachusetts</div></div></div>
<p>Vegetarianism can be traced to Ancient <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ancient_India&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ancient India (page does not exist)">India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">Greece</a>, but the word <i>vegetarian</i> came into use in English in the 19th century to refer to those who avoided meat. <i>The Oxford English Dictionary</i> attributes the earliest use of the word to the English actress <a href="/wiki/Fanny_Kemble" title="Fanny Kemble">Fanny Kemble</a> (1809–1893), writing in Georgia in the United States in 1839.<sup id="cite_ref-Kemble_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kemble-9">[9]</a></sup> Vegetarians who also avoided eggs and dairy products, or avoided using animals for any purpose, were referred to as strict or total vegetarians.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>There were several attempts in the 19th century to establish vegan/strict-vegetarian communities. In the United States in 1834 <a href="/wiki/Amos_Bronson_Alcott" title="Amos Bronson Alcott">Amos Bronson Alcott</a> (1799–1888), a <a href="/wiki/Transcendentalism" title="Transcendentalism">transcendentalist</a> and father of the novelist <a href="/wiki/Louisa_May_Alcott" title="Louisa May Alcott">Louisa May Alcott</a> (1832–1888), opened the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Temple_School_(Massachusetts)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Temple School (Massachusetts) (page does not exist)">Temple School</a> in Boston, Massachusetts, on strict-vegetarian principles.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> In 1844 Alcott also founded <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fruitlands_(transcendental_center)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fruitlands (transcendental center) (page does not exist)">Fruitlands</a>, a community in Harvard, Massachusetts, that opposed the use of animals for any purpose, including farming, though it lasted only seven months.<sup id="cite_ref-Hart1995p14_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hart1995p14-12">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>In England in 1838 <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Pierrepont_Greaves&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Pierrepont Greaves (page does not exist)">James Pierrepont Greaves</a> (1777–1842) opened <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alcott_House&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alcott House (page does not exist)">Alcott House</a> in Ham, Surrey, a community that followed a strict-vegetarian diet.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> Members of Alcott House were involved in 1847 in forming the British <a href="/wiki/Vegetarian_Society" title="Vegetarian Society">Vegetarian Society</a>, which held its first meeting in September 1847 at Northwood Villa in Ramsgate, Kent, chaired by Salford MP <a href="/w/index.php?title=Joseph_Brotherton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Joseph Brotherton (page does not exist)">Joseph Brotherton</a> (1783–1857).<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Shift_toward_veganism">Shift toward veganism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gandhi_LVS_1931.jpg" title="File:Gandhi LVS 1931.jpg">File:Gandhi LVS 1931.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a> at the Vegetarian Society in London on 20 November 1931, with <a href="/wiki/Henry_Stephens_Salt" title="Henry Stephens Salt">Henry Salt</a> sitting to his right.<sup id="cite_ref-GandhiSalt_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GandhiSalt-15">[15]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Vegetarians who were interested in the moral aspects of diet, rather than its implications for human health, began to discuss abstaining from animal use entirely. An 1851 article in the Vegetarian Society's magazine discussed alternatives to leather for shoes.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> In 1886 the society published <i>A Plea for Vegetarianism</i> by the English campaigner <a href="/wiki/Henry_Stephens_Salt" title="Henry Stephens Salt">Henry Salt</a> (1851–1939), which argued for vegetarianism as a moral imperative; Salt later became one of the first to make the paradigm shift from the promotion of <a href="/wiki/Animal_welfare" title="Animal welfare">animal welfare</a> to the concept of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal rights (page does not exist)">animal rights</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup> His work influenced <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a> (1869–1948) and the men became friends.<sup id="cite_ref-GandhiSalt_15-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-GandhiSalt-15">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first known British vegan cookbook, <i>No Animal Food: Two Essays and 100 Recipes</i> by Rupert H. Wheldon, appeared in London in 1910.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> Historian Leah Leneman (1944–1999) wrote that there was a vigorous correspondence between 1909 and 1912 among members of the Vegetarian Society about dairy products and eggs. One reader wrote: "You cannot have eggs without also having on your hands a number of male birds, which you must kill."<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup> The Vegetarian Society's position remained unresolved, but its journal noted in 1923 that the "ideal position for vegetarians is abstinence from animal products."<sup id="cite_ref-Leneman1999p221_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Leneman1999p221-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 1931 Gandhi addressed a Vegetarian Society meeting in London – attended by around 500 members, including Henry Salt – and argued in a speech called "The Moral Basis of Vegetarianism" that the society ought to promote a meat-free diet as a moral issue, not only in the interests of human health.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> Gandhi told the society he had found in his student days in London that vegetarians talked of nothing but food and disease:
</p>
<blockquote>I feel that this is the worst way of going about the business. I notice also that it is those persons who become vegetarians because they are suffering from some disease or other – that is, from purely the health point of view – it is those persons who largely fall back. I discovered that for remaining staunch to vegetarianism a man requires a moral basis.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup></blockquote>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coining_the_term_vegan.2C_founding_the_Vegan_Society">Coining the term <i>vegan</i>, founding the Vegan Society</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Donald_watson.jpg" title="File:Donald watson.jpg">File:Donald watson.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Watson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Donald Watson (page does not exist)">Donald Watson</a> coined the term <i>vegan</i> and founded the British <a href="/wiki/Vegan_Society" title="Vegan Society">Vegan Society</a> in 1944.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1935 the Vegetarian Society's journal observed that the issue of whether vegetarians ought to eat dairy products and eggs was becoming more pressing with every year.<sup id="cite_ref-Leneman1999p221_20-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Leneman1999p221-20">[20]</a></sup> In July 1943 Leslie J. Cross, a member of the Leicester Vegetarian Society, expressed concern in its newsletter, <i>The Vegetarian Messenger</i>, that vegetarians were still consuming cow's milk.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Cross echoed the argument about eggs, that to produce milk for human consumption the cow has to be separated from her calves soon after their birth: "in order to produce a dairy cow, heart-rending cruelty, and not merely exploitation, is a necessity."<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup>
</p><p>In August 1944 some of the Vegetarian Society's members, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Donald_Watson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Donald Watson (page does not exist)">Donald Watson</a> (1910–2005), asked the Vegetarian Society if they could have a section of the society's magazine to discuss non-dairy vegetarianism. They were told no, and so Watson wrote a letter to the magazine saying that he wanted to set up his own quarterly newsletter. In response, 30 readers sent him a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Shilling_(British_coin)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Shilling (British coin) (page does not exist)">shilling</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Watson_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>Watson issued the first newsletter in November 1944 and called it <i>Vegan News</i> (<span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA">/ˈviːɡən/</span>, with the stress on the first syllable); the word was composed of the first three and last two letters of vegetarian, which he said represented "the beginning and end of vegetarian."<sup id="cite_ref-Watsoninterview_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watsoninterview-26">[26]</a></sup> The newsletter was priced tuppence (two <a href="/w/index.php?title=Penny_(British_pre-decimal_coin)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Penny (British pre-decimal coin) (page does not exist)">pennies</a>, 2d), or one shilling (1/-) for a year's subscription.<sup id="cite_ref-Watson_25-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-25">[25]</a></sup> Watson asked readers if they had suggestions other than <i>vegan</i> to describe non-dairy vegetarian. They suggested <i>allvega</i>, <i>neo-vegetarian</i>, <i>dairyban</i>, <i>vitan</i>, <i>benevore</i>, <i>sanivores</i> and <i>beaumangeur</i>, but decided to stick with <i>vegan</i>. The new Vegan Society held its first annual meeting on 15 December 1945 at the Attic Club, <a href="/wiki/High_Holborn" title="High Holborn">High Holborn</a>, London.<sup id="cite_ref-Watson_25-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Watson-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>Two vegan books appeared around this time. The Leicester Vegetarian Society published <i>Vegetarian Recipes without Dairy Produce</i>, a booklet by Margaret B. Rawls, and in the summer of 1946 the Vegan Society published <i>Vegan Recipes</i> by Fay K. Henderson.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> In 1951 the Vegan Society broadened its definition of veganism to "the doctrine that man should live without exploiting animals," and pledged to seek an end to the use of animals "for food, commodities, work, hunting, vivisection and all other uses involving exploitation of animal life by man."<sup id="cite_ref-Cross1951_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cross1951-28">[28]</a></sup> In 1956 Leslie Cross founded the Plantmilk Society to explore how to produce a commercial <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a>, and as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plamil_Foods&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plamil Foods (page does not exist)">Plamil Foods Ltd</a> it began production in 1965 of one of the first widely distributed soy milks in the Western world.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Joanne_Stepaniak" title="Joanne Stepaniak">Joanne Stepaniak</a>, the word <i>vegan</i> was independently published for the first time in 1962, in the <i>Oxford Illustrated Dictionary</i>, defined as "a vegetarian who eats no butter, eggs, cheese or milk."<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/World_Vegan_Day" title="World Vegan Day">World Vegan Day</a>, held every 1 November, was established in 1994 to mark the society's founding date.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Founding_the_American_Vegan_Society">Founding the American Vegan Society</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The first vegan society in the United States was founded in 1948 by nurse and chiropractor Catherine Nimmo (1887–1985) of Oceano, California, and Rubin Abramowitz of Los Angeles. Originally from the Netherlands, Nimmo had been a vegan since 1931, and when the British Vegan Society was founded she began distributing its newsletter, <i>The Vegan News</i>, to her mailing list within the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> In 1957 <a href="/w/index.php?title=H._Jay_Dinshah&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="H. Jay Dinshah (page does not exist)">H. Jay Dinshah</a> (1933–2000), the son of a <a href="/wiki/Parsi" title="Parsi">Parsi</a> from Mumbai, visited a slaughterhouse and read some of Watson's literature. He gave up all animal products, and on 8 February 1960 founded the American Vegan Society (AVS) in Malaga, New Jersey. He incorporated Nimmo's society and linked veganism to the concept of <i>ahimsa</i>, a Sanskrit word meaning "non-harming." The AVS called this "dynamic harmlessness" and named its magazine <i>Ahimsa</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Achieving_mainstream_acceptance_.282000s.E2.80.932010s.29">Achieving mainstream acceptance (2000s–2010s)</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Save_The_World_Awards_2009_show06_-_Carl_Lewis.jpg" title="File:Save The World Awards 2009 show06 - Carl Lewis.jpg">File:Save The World Awards 2009 show06 - Carl Lewis.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Athlete <a href="/wiki/Carl_Lewis" title="Carl Lewis">Carl Lewis</a> adopted a vegan diet in 1990.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>From the late 1970s a group of scientists in the United States – physicians <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_A._McDougall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John A. McDougall (page does not exist)">John A. McDougall</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Caldwell_Esselstyn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Caldwell Esselstyn (page does not exist)">Caldwell Esselstyn</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neal_D._Barnard" title="Neal D. Barnard">Neal D. Barnard</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dean_Ornish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dean Ornish (page does not exist)">Dean Ornish</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Greger&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Greger (page does not exist)">Michael Greger</a>, and biochemist <a href="/w/index.php?title=T._Colin_Campbell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="T. Colin Campbell (page does not exist)">T. Colin Campbell</a> – began to argue that diets based on <a href="/wiki/Animal_fat" title="Animal fat">animal fat</a> and animal protein, such as the <a href="/wiki/Standard_American_Diet" title="Standard American Diet" class="mw-redirect">standard American diet</a>, were detrimental to health. They proposed that a low-fat, plant-based diet would prevent, and might reverse, certain chronic diseases, such as coronary heart disease, diabetes and certain cancers.<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup> Dr. <a href="/wiki/Sanjay_Gupta" title="Sanjay Gupta">Sanjay Gupta</a>, CNN's chief medical correspondent, said in his documentary <i>The Last Heart Attack</i> (2011) that T. Colin Campbell's <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_China_Study_(book)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The China Study (book) (page does not exist)">The China Study</a></i> (2005) had changed the way people all over the world eat, including Gupta himself.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2011 the Associated Press reported that in the United States the vegan diet was "moving from marginal to mainstream," with vegan books such as <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Skinny_Bitch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Skinny Bitch (page does not exist)">Skinny Bitch</a></i> (2005) becoming best sellers. In a 2011 poll over half the 1,500 chefs polled said vegan entrees were becoming popular, and chain restaurants began to mark vegan items on their menus.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vegetarianism_and_veganism_page_views,_Wikipedia.jpg" title="File:Vegetarianism and veganism page views, Wikipedia.jpg">File:Vegetarianism and veganism page views, Wikipedia.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The interest in veganism in the 2010s was reflected in increased page views for veganism on Wikipedia.<sup id="cite_ref-pageviews_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pageviews-38">[38]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>The interest in veganism in the 2010s was reflected in increased page views on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wikipedia (page does not exist)">Wikipedia</a>. The English Wikipedia article on veganism was viewed 73,000 times in August 2009 but 145,000 times in August 2013; articles on veganism were viewed more during this period than articles on vegetarianism in the English, French, German, Portuguese, Russian and Spanish Wikipedias.<sup id="cite_ref-pageviews_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pageviews-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 2010 the European Parliament adopted a food-labelling guideline that defined "vegan" (in force as of 2015): "The term 'vegan' shall not be applied to foods that are, or are made from or with the aid of, animals or animal products, including products from living animals."<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> The first known vegetarian butcher shop, <i>De Vegetarische Slager</i>, opened in the Netherlands in 2010, selling "mock meats"; as of September 2011 there were 30 branches in the Netherlands and Belgium.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> Europe's first vegan supermarkets appeared in Germany in 2011. Vegilicious opened in Dortmund,<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> and the first chain, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Veganz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Veganz (page does not exist)">Veganz</a>, opened in Berlin and other locations; the latter planned to have 21 stores in Europe by the end of 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-Mesure8Dec2013_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mesure8Dec2013-42">[42]</a></sup> In 2013 the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oktoberfest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oktoberfest (page does not exist)">Oktoberfest</a> in Munich  – traditionally a meat-heavy affair – offered vegan dishes for the first time in its 200-year history.<sup id="cite_ref-Guttman4Oct2013_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guttman4Oct2013-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>Celebrities, athletes and politicians began to adopt vegan diets, some seriously, some part-time. Former US president <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> and vice-president <a href="/w/index.php?title=Al_Gore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Al Gore (page does not exist)">Al Gore</a> turned to veganism, Clinton in 2010 (part-time by 2013), and Gore in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oprah_Winfrey&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oprah Winfrey (page does not exist)">Oprah Winfrey</a> tried it for 21 days and Dr. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mehmet_Oz&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mehmet Oz (page does not exist)">Mehmet Oz</a>, a vegetarian, recommended it.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> The boxer <a href="/wiki/Mike_Tyson" title="Mike Tyson">Mike Tyson</a> and businessmen <a href="/wiki/William_Clay_Ford,_Jr." title="William Clay Ford, Jr.">William Clay Ford, Jr.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Joi_Ito" title="Joi Ito">Joi Ito</a>, <a href="/wiki/John_Mackey_(businessman)" title="John Mackey (businessman)">John Mackey</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russell_Simmons" title="Russell Simmons">Russell Simmons</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Biz_Stone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Biz Stone (page does not exist)">Biz Stone</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Steve_Wynn_(entrepreneur)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Steve Wynn (entrepreneur) (page does not exist)">Steve Wynn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mortimer_Zuckerman" title="Mortimer Zuckerman">Mortimer Zuckerman</a> were all reported to have become dietary vegans in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup> The idea of the "flexi-vegan" gained currency, to the irritation of ethical vegans; in his book <i>VB6</i> (2013), <i>New York Times</i> food columnist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mark_Bittman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mark Bittman (page does not exist)">Mark Bittman</a> recommended sticking to a vegan diet before 6 pm.<sup id="cite_ref-Mesure8Dec2013_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mesure8Dec2013-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics_.281996.E2.80.93present.29">Demographics (1996–present)</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Oktoberfest_inside_Hippodrom.jpg" title="File:Oktoberfest inside Hippodrom.jpg">File:Oktoberfest inside Hippodrom.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Munich's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oktoberfest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oktoberfest (page does not exist)">Oktoberfest</a> offered vegan dishes for the first time in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-Guttman4Oct2013_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guttman4Oct2013-43">[43]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Surveys in the United States between 1996 and 2012 suggested that between 0.5 and three percent (1.5 to over nine million people) in that country were vegan. In 1996 three percent said they did not use animals for any purpose.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47">[47]</a></sup> A 2006 Harris Interactive poll suggested that 1.4 percent were dietary vegans; a 2008 survey for the Vegetarian Resource Group (VRG) reported 0.5 percent; a 2009 VRG survey said that it was one percent (two million out of a population of 313 million, or one in 150); and a 2012 Gallup poll reported two percent.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup>
</p><p>In Europe the <i>Times</i> of London estimated in 2005 that there were 250,000 vegans in the UK (out of a population of 60 million), in 2006 <i>The Independent</i> estimated 600,000, and in 2007 two percent of respondents in a British government survey self-identified as vegan.<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup> The British market for tofu and mock meats was £786.5 million a year in 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> The Netherlands Association for Veganism estimated that there were 16,000 vegans in the Netherlands as of 2007, around 0.1 percent of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> The German Vegetarian Society said in 2013 that there were 800,000 vegans in Germany (out of a population of nearly 82 million).<sup id="cite_ref-Guttman4Oct2013_43-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Guttman4Oct2013-43">[43]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Animal_products">Animal products</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Avoidance">Avoidance</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Homelard.jpg" title="File:Homelard.jpg">File:Homelard.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Lard from pigs</div></div></div>
<p>The issue that divided the 19th- and early 20th-century vegetarians – whether to avoid animal products for reasons of ethics or health – persists. Dietary vegans avoid consuming any animal products (no meat, fish, eggs or dairy products), but may use them in clothing and toiletries.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> Against this, ethical vegans see veganism as a philosophy. They reject the <a href="/wiki/Commodification" title="Commodification">commodification</a> of animals and will not use them for food, clothing, entertainment or any other purpose.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> The British Vegan Society will only certify a product if it is free of animal involvement as far as possible and practical, including <a href="/wiki/Animal_testing" title="Animal testing">animal testing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p>Animal products include meat, poultry, seafood, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Egg_(food)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Egg (food) (page does not exist)">eggs</a>, dairy products, honey, fur, leather, wool and silk. Less well-known animal products are <a href="/wiki/Beeswax" title="Beeswax">beeswax</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bone_char" title="Bone char">bone char</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bone_china" title="Bone china">bone china</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carmine" title="Carmine">carmine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Casein" title="Casein">casein</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cochineal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cochineal (page does not exist)">cochineal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gelatin" title="Gelatin">gelatin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Isinglass" title="Isinglass">isinglass</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lanolin" title="Lanolin">lanolin</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lard&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lard (page does not exist)">lard</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rennet" title="Rennet">rennet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shellac" title="Shellac">shellac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tallow" title="Tallow">tallow</a>, <a href="/wiki/Whey" title="Whey">whey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yellow_grease" title="Yellow grease">yellow grease</a>. Many of these may not be identified in the list of ingredients in the finished product.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup>
</p><p>Ethical vegans will not use these products and will try to avoid anything tested on animals. They will not buy fur coats, leather shoes, cars with leather seats, woollen jumpers, silk scarves, camera film, bedding that contains goose down or duck feathers, and will not use certain vaccines; the production of the flu vaccine, for example, involves the use of chicken eggs. Depending on their circumstances, vegans may donate non-vegan items to charity or use them until they wear out. Alternatives to wool include acrylic, cotton, hemp, rayon and polyester. Some vegan clothes, in particular shoes and leather alternatives, are made of petroleum-based products, which has triggered criticism because of the environmental damage associated with production.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Milk.2C_eggs.2C_honey_and_silk">Milk, eggs, honey and silk</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Smoker.jpg" title="File:Smoker.jpg">File:Smoker.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Vegans differ about honey.</div></div></div>
<p>The main difference between a vegan and vegetarian diet is that vegans exclude eggs and dairy products; ethical vegans state that the production of eggs and dairy causes animal suffering and premature death. In both <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battery_cage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battery cage (page does not exist)">battery cage</a> and <a href="/wiki/Free-range_eggs" title="Free-range eggs">free-range egg</a> production, most male <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chick_culling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chick culling (page does not exist)">chicks are culled</a> because they will not lay eggs and there is no financial incentive for a producer to keep them.<sup id="cite_ref-egg_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-egg-57">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>To obtain milk from <a href="/wiki/Dairy_cattle" title="Dairy cattle">dairy cattle</a>, cows are kept pregnant through <a href="/wiki/Artificial_insemination" title="Artificial insemination">artificial insemination</a> to prolong <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lactation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lactation (page does not exist)">lactation</a>. Male calves are slaughtered at birth, sent for <a href="/wiki/Veal" title="Veal">veal</a> production or reared for beef. Female calves are separated from their mothers within 24–48 hours of birth and fed milk replacer, so that the cow's milk is retained for human consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-milk_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-milk-58">[58]</a></sup> After about five years they are slaughtered to be made into ground-meat products, although they might otherwise live for 20 years.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup> The situation is similar with goats and their <a href="/w/index.php?title=Goat&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Goat (page does not exist)">kids</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is disagreement among vegan groups about the extent to which products from insects should be avoided. Ethical vegans will not use silk, a protein obtained from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Silkworm&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Silkworm (page does not exist)">silkworms</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> Most vegans also regard modern beekeeping as cruel and exploitative; once the honey (the bees' natural food store) is harvested, it is substituted with sugar or <a href="/wiki/Corn_syrup" title="Corn syrup">corn syrup</a> to maintain the colony.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> Neither the Vegan Society nor the American Vegan Society considers the use of honey, silk or other insect products to be suitable for vegans, while Vegan Action and Vegan Outreach regard it as a matter of personal choice.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Agave_nectar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Agave nectar (page does not exist)">Agave nectar</a> is a popular vegan alternative to honey.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Vegan_diet">Vegan diet</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Common_dishes_and_ingredients">Common dishes and ingredients</span></h3>
<dl>
<dd><i>Further information: <a href="/w/index.php?title=B:Category:Vegan_recipes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="B:Category:Vegan recipes (page does not exist)">Vegan recipes</a></i>
</dd>
</dl>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soy_milk.jpg" title="File:Soy milk.jpg">File:Soy milk.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">Soy milk</a> is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Complete_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Complete protein (page does not exist)">complete protein</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Common vegan dishes include chilis and soups, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ratatouille&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ratatouille (page does not exist)">ratatouille</a>, <a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus</a>, veggie <a href="/w/index.php?title=Burrito&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Burrito (page does not exist)">burritos</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_and_beans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice and beans (page does not exist)">rice and beans</a>, veggie stir-fry, veggie burgers, and various pasta dishes like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pasta_primavera&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pasta primavera (page does not exist)">pasta primavera</a>.
</p><p>Ingredients made from <a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">soybeans</a> are a staple of vegan diets because soybeans are a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Complete_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Complete protein (page does not exist)">complete protein</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Mangels2011p256_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mangels2011p256-65">[65]</a></sup> They are consumed most often in the form of <a href="/wiki/Soy_milk" title="Soy milk">soy milk</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tofu (page does not exist)">tofu</a> (bean curd), which is soy milk mixed with a coagulant; tofu comes in a variety of textures, depending on water content, from firm, medium firm and extra firm for stews and stir-fries, to soft or silken for salad dressings, desserts and shakes. Soy is also eaten in the form of <a href="/wiki/Tempeh" title="Tempeh">tempeh</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Texturized_vegetable_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Texturized vegetable protein (page does not exist)">texturized vegetable protein</a> (TVP) (also known as textured soy protein, TSP); the latter is often used in pasta sauces.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>The wheat-based <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seitan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seitan (page does not exist)">seitan</a>/<a href="/wiki/Gluten" title="Gluten">gluten</a> is another common source of plant protein. <a href="/wiki/Meat_analogue" title="Meat analogue">Meat analogues</a>, or mock meats, also based on soy or gluten, come in the form of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vegetarian_sausage&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vegetarian sausage (page does not exist)">vegetarian sausage</a>, vegetarian mince and <a href="/wiki/Veggie_burger" title="Veggie burger">veggie burgers</a>, and are usually free of animal products.
</p><p>{{#invoke:anchor|main}}
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Plant_milk.2C_ice-cream_and_cheese">Plant milk, ice-cream and cheese</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Plant_cream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plant cream (page does not exist)">Plant cream</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Plant_milk&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Plant milk (page does not exist)">plant milk</a> – such as soy milk, <a href="/wiki/Almond_milk" title="Almond milk">almond milk</a>, <a href="/wiki/Grain_milk" title="Grain milk">grain milk</a> (oat milk and <a href="/wiki/Rice_milk" title="Rice milk">rice milk</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Coconut_milk" title="Coconut milk">coconut milk</a> – are used instead of cows' or goats' milk. The most widely available are soy and almond milk. Soy milk provides around 7 g of protein <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cup_(unit)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cup (unit) (page does not exist)">per cup</a> (250 ml or 8 fluid ounces), compared with 8 g of protein per cup of cow's milk. Almond milk has fewer calories but less protein.<sup id="cite_ref-Reinagel2011p20-21_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Reinagel2011p20-21-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>Like animal milk and meat, soy milk is a complete protein, meaning that it contains all the <a href="/wiki/Essential_amino_acid" title="Essential amino acid">essential amino acids</a> and can be relied upon entirely for protein intake.<sup id="cite_ref-Mangels2011p256_65-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mangels2011p256-65">[65]</a></sup> Soy milk alone should not be used as a replacement for breast milk for babies; babies who are not breastfed need commercial <a href="/wiki/Infant_formula" title="Infant formula">infant formula</a>, which is normally based on cow's milk or soy (the latter is known as <a href="/wiki/Soybean#Infant_formula" title="Soybean">soy-based infant formula</a> or SBIF).<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:30%; float: right;">
<caption>
</caption>
<tr>
<td>
</td>
<th scope="col"> Cow's milk (whole)<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup>
</th>
<th scope="col"> Soy milk<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row"> Calories (per <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cup_(unit)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cup (unit) (page does not exist)">cup</a>)
</th>
<td>149
</td>
<td>80
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row"> Fat
</th>
<td>7.9 g
</td>
<td>4 g
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row"> Saturated fat
</th>
<td>4.6 g
</td>
<td>0.5 g
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th scope="row"> Cholesterol
</th>
<td>24&#160;mg
</td>
<td>0&#160;mg
</td></tr>

<tr>
<th scope="row"> Sodium
</th>
<td>105&#160;mg
</td>
<td>100&#160;mg
</td></tr>

<tr>
<th scope="row"> Potassium
</th>
<td>322&#160;mg
</td>
<td>300&#160;mg
</td></tr>

<tr>
<th scope="row"> Carbohydrate
</th>
<td>12 g
</td>
<td>4 g
</td></tr>

<tr>
<th scope="row"> Protein
</th>
<td>8 g
</td>
<td>7 g
</td></tr></table>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cheese_analogue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cheese analogue (page does not exist)">Cheese analogues</a> are made from soy, nuts and <a href="/wiki/Tapioca" title="Tapioca">tapioca</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> Vegan cheeses like <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chreese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chreese (page does not exist)">Chreese</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Daiya&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Daiya (page does not exist)">Daiya</a>, Sheese, Teese and Tofutti can replace both the taste and meltability of dairy cheese.<sup id="cite_ref-Barnouin_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Barnouin-72">[72]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Nutritional_yeast" title="Nutritional yeast">Nutritional yeast</a> is a common cheese substitute in vegan recipes.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> Cheese substitutes can be made at home, using recipes from Joanne Stepaniak's <i>Vegan Vittles</i> (1996), <i>The Nutritional Yeast Cookbook</i> (1997), and <i>The Uncheese Cookbook</i> (2003), and Mikoyo Schinner's <i>Artisan Vegan Cheese</i> (2012).<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> One recipe for vegan brie involves combining cashews, soy yogurt and coconut oil.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> Butter can be replaced with a vegan margarine such as Earth Balance.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Egg_replacements">Egg replacements</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Vegan (egg-free) mayonnaise brands include Vegenaise, Nayonaise, Miso Mayo, and Plamil's Egg-Free Mayo.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> Eggs are used in recipes as thickeners and binders; the protein in eggs thickens when heated and binds the other ingredients together.<sup id="cite_ref-Mangels2011p445_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mangels2011p445-78">[78]</a></sup> This effect can be achieved in vegan recipes with ground <a href="/wiki/Flax_seed" title="Flax seed" class="mw-redirect">flax seeds</a>; replace each egg in a recipe with one <a href="/wiki/Tablespoon" title="Tablespoon">tablespoon</a> of flaxseed meal mixed with three tablespoons of water. Commercial egg substitutes, such as Bob's Red Mill egg replacer and Ener-G egg replacer, are also available.<sup id="cite_ref-Esselstyn2007p266_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Esselstyn2007p266-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>For vegan pancakes a tablespoon of <a href="/wiki/Baking_powder" title="Baking powder">baking powder</a> can be used instead of eggs.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> Other ingredients include, to replace one egg, one tablespoon of <a href="/wiki/Soy_flour" title="Soy flour" class="mw-redirect">soy flour</a> and one tablespoon of water; a quarter cup of mashed bananas, mashed prunes or apple sauce; or  in <a href="/wiki/Batter_(cooking)" title="Batter (cooking)">batter</a> two tablespoons of white flour, half a tablespoon of vegetable oil, two tablespoons of water and half a tablespoon of baking powder.<sup id="cite_ref-Mangels2011p445_78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mangels2011p445-78">[78]</a></sup> Silken (soft) tofu and mashed potato can also be used.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Vegan_food_groups">Vegan food groups</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Side_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Side box (page does not exist)">Template:Side box</a>
Since 1991 the <a href="/wiki/Physicians_Committee_for_Responsible_Medicine" title="Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine">Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine</a> (PCRM) has recommended a no-cholesterol, low-fat vegan diet based on what they call the Four New Food Groups: fruit, <a href="/wiki/Legume" title="Legume">legumes</a>, grains, and vegetables. Legumes include peas, <a href="/wiki/Beans" title="Beans" class="mw-redirect">beans</a>, lentils and peanuts. PCRM recommends three or more servings a day of fruit (at least one of which is high in vitamin C, such as citrus fruit, melon or strawberries), two or more of protein-rich legumes (such as soybeans, which can be consumed as soy milk, tofu or tempeh), five or more of <a href="/wiki/Whole_grain" title="Whole grain">whole grains</a> (such as corn, barley, rice and wheat, in products such as bread and tortillas), and four or more of vegetables (dark-green leafy vegetables such as broccoli, and dark-yellow and orange such as carrots or sweet potatoes).<sup id="cite_ref-foodgroups_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-foodgroups-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>The PCRM vegan food group was intended to replace the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Four_Food_Groups&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Four Food Groups (page does not exist)">Four Food Groups</a> – meat, milk, vegetables and fruit, and cereal and breads – recommended by the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) from 1956 until 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> In 1992 the USDA replaced its model with the <a href="/wiki/Food_guide_pyramid" title="Food guide pyramid">food guide pyramid</a>, and in 2011 with <a href="/w/index.php?title=MyPlate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MyPlate (page does not exist)">MyPlate</a>, which is divided into five food groups: grains, vegetables, fruits, dairy, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protein_(nutrient)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protein (nutrient) (page does not exist)">protein</a> (meat, poultry, seafood, beans and peas, eggs, processed soy products, nuts and seeds).<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> In the UK the government recommends the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eatwell_plate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eatwell plate (page does not exist)">eatwell plate</a>, also with five food groups, which are consistent with veganism: fruits and vegetables; potatoes, bread and other starchy foods; dairy products (which can be swapped for vegan alternatives); meat, fish, eggs or beans for protein; and fat and sugar.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nutrients">Nutrients</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Protein">Protein</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Red_beans_and_rice.jpg" title="File:Red beans and rice.jpg">File:Red beans and rice.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_and_beans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice and beans (page does not exist)">Rice and beans</a> is a common vegan <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protein_combining&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protein combining (page does not exist)">protein combination</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">Proteins</a> are composed of <a href="/wiki/Amino_acid" title="Amino acid">amino acids</a>. Nutritionist <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reed_Mangels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reed Mangels (page does not exist)">Reed Mangels</a> writes that <a href="/w/index.php?title=Omnivore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Omnivore (page does not exist)">omnivores</a> generally obtain a third of their protein from plant foods, and ovo-lacto vegetarians a half.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> Vegans obtain all their protein from plant sources. A common question is whether plant protein supplies an adequate amount of the <a href="/wiki/Essential_amino_acid" title="Essential amino acid">essential amino acids</a>, which cannot be synthesized by the human body.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup>
</p><p>Sources of plant protein include legumes, such as soy beans (consumed as tofu, tempeh, texturized vegetable protein, soy milk and <a href="/wiki/Edamame" title="Edamame">edamame</a>), peas, peanuts, black beans and chickpeas (the latter often eaten as <a href="/wiki/Hummus" title="Hummus">hummus</a>); grains such as <a href="/wiki/Quinoa" title="Quinoa">quinoa</a> (pronounced <i>keenwa</i>), brown rice, corn, barley, bulgur and wheat (often eaten as whole-wheat bread and seitan); and nuts and seeds, such as almonds, hemp and sunflower seeds.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>Soy beans and quinoa are known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Complete_protein&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Complete protein (page does not exist)">complete proteins</a> because they each contain all the essential amino acids.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> Mangels et al. write that consuming the <a href="/wiki/Recommended_dietary_allowance" title="Recommended dietary allowance" class="mw-redirect">recommended dietary allowance</a> (RDA) of protein (0.8 g/kg body weight) in the form of soy will meet the biologic requirement for amino acids. They add that the United States Department of Agriculture has ruled that soy protein may replace meat protein in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=School_meal_programs_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="School meal programs in the United States (page does not exist)">Federal School Lunch Program</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Mangels2011p256_65-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mangels2011p256-65">[65]</a></sup>
</p><p>Traditional combinations that contain high amounts of all the essential amino acids are <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rice_and_beans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rice and beans (page does not exist)">rice and beans</a>, corn and beans, and hummus and whole-wheat pita. The American Dietetic Association said in 2009 that a variety of plant foods consumed over the course of a day can provide all the essential amino acids for healthy adults, which means that <a href="/w/index.php?title=Protein_combining&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Protein combining (page does not exist)">protein combining</a> in the same meal may not be necessary.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> Mangels et al. write that there is little reason to advise vegans to increase their protein intake, but erring on the side of caution (taking into account the lower digestibility and poorer amino acid pattern of plant protein), they would recommend a 25 percent increase over the RDA for adults, to 1.0 gram of protein per kilogram of body weight.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vitamin_B12">Vitamin B12</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Seitan.jpg" title="File:Seitan.jpg">File:Seitan.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Mock meats, such as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seitan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seitan (page does not exist)">seitan</a>, are often fortified with vitamin B12.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_B12&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin B12 (page does not exist)">Vitamin B12</a> is a bacterial product needed for <a href="/wiki/Cell_division" title="Cell division">cell division</a>, the formation and maturation of <a href="/wiki/Red_blood_cell" title="Red blood cell">red blood cells</a>, the <a href="/wiki/DNA_synthesis" title="DNA synthesis">synthesis of DNA</a>, and normal <a href="/wiki/Nerve" title="Nerve">nerve</a> function. A deficiency can lead to several health problems, including <a href="/wiki/Megaloblastic_anemia" title="Megaloblastic anemia">megaloblastic anemia</a> and nerve damage.<sup id="cite_ref-Mangels_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mangels-92">[92]</a></sup> The consensus among nutritionists is that vegans and even vegetarians should eat foods fortified with B12 or use supplements.<sup id="cite_ref-B12extra_8-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-B12extra-8">[8]</a></sup> That vegans are unable in most cases, at least in the West, to obtain B12 from a plant-based diet is often used as an argument against veganism.<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p><p>Neither plants nor animals make B12; it is produced by microorganisms, such as bacteria, fungi and algae. <a href="/wiki/Herbivorous" title="Herbivorous" class="mw-redirect">Herbivorous</a> animals obtain it from bacteria in their <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rumen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rumen (page does not exist)">rumens</a>, either by absorbing it or by eating their own <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cecotrope&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cecotrope (page does not exist)">cecotrope</a> faeces; rabbits, for example, produce and eat cecal pellets. When those animals are eaten, they become sources of B12. Plants from the ground that are not washed properly may contain B12 from bacteria in the soil, often from faeces; drinking water may also be contaminated with B12-producing bacteria, particularly in the developing world.<sup id="cite_ref-Mangels_92-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Mangels-92">[92]</a></sup> Mangels et al. write that bacteria in the human digestive tract produce B12, but most of it is not absorbed and is expelled in the faeces, with tiny amounts also expelled in the urine. James Halsted, a medical researcher, reported in the 1960s that a group of villagers in Iran eating very little or no animal protein were found to have normal B12 levels because they were living with animal manure near their homes, and were eating vegetables grown in human manure (known as <a href="/wiki/Night_soil" title="Night soil">night soil</a>) and not thoroughly washed. The human mouth is another source of B12, but in small amounts and possibly analogue (not biologically active).<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Tofu_with_spinach_and_mushrooms.JPG" title="File:Tofu with spinach and mushrooms.JPG">File:Tofu with spinach and mushrooms.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Tofu&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tofu (page does not exist)">Tofu</a> (soybeans) with spinach and mushroom</div></div></div>
<p>Western vegan diets are likely to be deficient in B12 because of increased hygiene. Vegans can obtain B12 by taking a supplement or by eating fortified foods, such as fortified soy milk or cereal, where it may be listed as <a href="/wiki/Cobalamin" title="Cobalamin">cobalamin</a> or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cyanocobalamin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cyanocobalamin (page does not exist)">cyanocobalamin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> B12 supplements are produced industrially through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bacterial_fermentation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bacterial fermentation (page does not exist)">bacterial fermentation-synthesis</a>; no animal products are involved in that process. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recommended_Dietary_Allowance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recommended Dietary Allowance (page does not exist)">RDA</a> for adults (14+ years) is 2.4 <a href="/wiki/Microgram" title="Microgram">mcg</a> (or µg) a day, rising to 2.4 and 2.6 mcg for pregnancy and lactation respectively; 0.4 mcg for 0–6 months, 0.5 mcg for 7–12 months, 0.9 mcg for 1–3 years, 1.2 mcg for 4–8 years, and 1.8 mcg for 9–13 years.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p><p>There is some disagreement within the vegan community as to whether supplementation is needed; several studies of vegans who did not take supplements or eat fortified food, including in Western countries, have found no sign of B12 deficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> According to Mangels et al., the disagreement is caused in part by the lack of a gold standard for assessing B12 status, and also because there are very few studies of long-term vegans who have not used supplements or fortified foods.<sup id="cite_ref-MangelsMessina2011p182_98-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MangelsMessina2011p182-98">[98]</a></sup> There are reports that certain plant foods are sources of B12; fermented foods such as tempeh and <a href="/wiki/Miso" title="Miso">miso</a>, as well as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edible_seaweed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edible seaweed (page does not exist)">edible seaweed</a> (such as <a href="/wiki/Arame" title="Arame">arame</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wakame" title="Wakame">wakame</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nori" title="Nori">nori</a>, and kombo), <a href="/wiki/Spirulina_(dietary_supplement)" title="Spirulina (dietary supplement)">spirulina</a>, and certain greens, grains and legumes, have been cited as B12 sources, as has rainwater. According to Mangels et al., tiny amounts have been found in <a href="/wiki/Barley_malt_syrup" title="Barley malt syrup">barley malt syrup</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shiitake" title="Shiitake">shiitake mushrooms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parsley" title="Parsley">parsley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sourdough" title="Sourdough">sourdough</a> bread, and higher amounts in spirulina and nori, but these products may be sources of inactive B12.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> They write that all Western vegans not using supplements or eating fortified foods will probably develop a B12 deficiency, although it may take decades to appear.<sup id="cite_ref-MangelsMessina2011p182_98-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MangelsMessina2011p182-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Calcium">Calcium</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bokchoycooked.jpg" title="File:Bokchoycooked.jpg">File:Bokchoycooked.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Bok_choi" title="Bok choi" class="mw-redirect">Bok choi</a> is high in calcium.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">Calcium</a> is needed to maintain <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bone_density&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bone density (page does not exist)">bone health</a>, and for a number of <a href="/wiki/Metabolism" title="Metabolism">metabolic</a> functions, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=Muscle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Muscle (page does not exist)">muscle function</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muscle_contraction" title="Muscle contraction">vascular contraction</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vasodilation" title="Vasodilation">vasodilation</a>, nerve transmission, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cell_signaling&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cell signaling (page does not exist)">intracellular signalling</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hormone" title="Hormone">hormonal</a> secretion. Ninety-nine percent of the body's calcium is stored in the bones and teeth. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recommended_Dietary_Allowance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recommended Dietary Allowance (page does not exist)">RDA</a> is 200&#160;mg for 0–6 months, 260&#160;mg for 7–12 months, 700&#160;mg for 1–3 years, 1,000&#160;mg for 4–8 years, 1,300&#160;mg for 9–18 years, 1,000&#160;mg for 19–50 years, 1,000&#160;mg for 51–70 years (men) and 1,200&#160;mg (women), and 1,200&#160;mg for 71+ years.<sup id="cite_ref-calcium-NIH_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-calcium-NIH-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vegans are advised to eat three servings per day of a high-calcium food, such as fortified soy milk, fortified tofu, almonds or hazelnuts, and to take a supplement as necessary.<sup id="cite_ref-dietitians_7-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dietitians-7">[7]</a></sup> Plant sources include broccoli, turnip and cabbage, such as Chinese cabbage (<a href="/wiki/Bok_choi" title="Bok choi" class="mw-redirect">bok choi</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Kale" title="Kale">kale</a>; the bioavailability of calcium in spinach is poor. Whole-wheat bread contains calcium; grains contain small amounts.<sup id="cite_ref-calcium-NIH_100-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-calcium-NIH-100">[100]</a></sup> Because vitamin D is needed for calcium absorption, vegans should make sure they also consume enough vitamin D (see <a href="#Vitamin_D">below</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=European_Prospective_Investigation_into_Cancer_and_Nutrition&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="European Prospective Investigation into Cancer and Nutrition (page does not exist)">EPIC-Oxford</a> study suggested that vegans have an increased risk of bone fractures over meat eaters and vegetarians, likely because of lower dietary calcium intake, but that vegans consuming more than 525&#160;mg/day have a risk of fractures similar to that of other groups.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> A 2009 study of bone density found the bone mineral density (BMD) of vegans was 94 percent that of omnivores, but deemed the difference clinically insignificant. Another study in 2009 by the same researchers examined over 100 vegan post-menopausal women, and found that their diet had no adverse effect on BMD and no alteration in body composition.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> Biochemist <a href="/w/index.php?title=T._Colin_Campbell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="T. Colin Campbell (page does not exist)">T. Colin Campbell</a> suggested in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_China_Study&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The China Study (page does not exist)">The China Study</a></i> (2005) that osteoporosis is linked to the consumption of animal protein; he argued that, unlike plant protein, animal protein increases the acidity of blood and tissues, which is then neutralized by calcium pulled from the bones.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vitamin_D">Vitamin D</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Sun_Edit1.jpg" title="File:The Sun Edit1.jpg">File:The Sun Edit1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">According to the <a href="/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health" title="National Institutes of Health">National Institutes of Health</a>, most people can obtain enough vitamin D from sunlight in the spring, summer and fall.<sup id="cite_ref-VitD-NIH_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VitD-NIH-105">[105]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin D (page does not exist)">Vitamin D</a> (calciferol) is needed for a number of functions, including calcium absorption, enabling mineralization of bone, and bone growth. Without it bones can become thin and brittle; together with calcium it offers protection against <a href="/wiki/Osteoporosis" title="Osteoporosis">osteoporosis</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-VitD-NIH_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VitD-NIH-105">[105]</a></sup> Mangels writes that it may also play a role in protecting against heart disease, diabetes, colon cancer, multiple sclerosis and dementia.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> Vitamin D is produced in the body when ultraviolet rays from the sun hit the skin; outdoor exposure is needed because UVB radiation does not penetrate glass. It is present in very few foods (mostly salmon, tuna, mackerel, cod liver oil, with small amounts in cheese, egg yolks and beef liver, and in some mushrooms).<sup id="cite_ref-VitD-NIH_105-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VitD-NIH-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most vegan diets contain little or no vitamin D, unless the food is fortified (such as fortified soy milk), so supplements may be needed depending on exposure to sunlight.<sup id="cite_ref-VitD-NIH_105-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VitD-NIH-105">[105]</a></sup> Vitamin D comes in two forms. <a href="/wiki/Cholecalciferol" title="Cholecalciferol">Cholecalciferol</a> (D3) is synthesized in the skin after exposure to the sun and may be consumed in the form of animal products; when produced industrially it is taken from <a href="/wiki/Lanolin" title="Lanolin">lanolin</a> in sheep's wool. <a href="/wiki/Ergocalciferol" title="Ergocalciferol">Ergocalciferol</a> (D2) is suitable for vegans; it is mostly human-made and is derived from <a href="/wiki/Ergosterol" title="Ergosterol">ergosterol</a> from yeast. Several conflicting studies have suggested that the two forms may or may not be bioequivalent.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> According to a 2011 report by the Food and Nutrition Board of the <a href="/wiki/National_Academy_of_Sciences" title="National Academy of Sciences">National Academy of Sciences</a>, the differences between D2 and D3 do not affect metabolism, both function as <a href="/wiki/Prohormone" title="Prohormone">prohormones</a>, and when activated exhibit identical responses in the body.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup>
</p><p>Supplements should be used with caution because vitamin D can be toxic, especially in children.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recommended_Dietary_Allowance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recommended Dietary Allowance (page does not exist)">RDA</a> is 10 mcg for 0–12 months, 15 mcg for 1–70 years, and 20 mcg for 70+.<sup id="cite_ref-VitD-NIH_105-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VitD-NIH-105">[105]</a></sup> People with little or no sun exposure may need more, perhaps up to 25 mcg daily.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> The daily <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tolerable_upper_intake_levels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tolerable upper intake levels (page does not exist)">tolerable upper intake level</a> (daily) for 9 years to adulthood is 100 mcg, according to the National Institutes of Health; for children it is 25 mcg for 0–6 months, 38 mcg for 7–12 months, 63 mcg for 1–3 years, and 75 mcg for 4–8 years.<sup id="cite_ref-VitD-NIH_105-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VitD-NIH-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>The extent to which sun exposure is sufficient to meet the body's needs will depend on the time of day, cloud and smog cover, skin <a href="/wiki/Melanin" title="Melanin">melanin</a> content, whether sunscreen is worn, and the season. According to the US <a href="/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health" title="National Institutes of Health">National Institutes of Health</a>, most people can obtain and store sufficient vitamin D from sunlight in the spring, summer and fall months, even in the far north. They report that some researchers recommend 5–30 minutes of sun exposure without sunscreen between ten in the morning and three o'clock in the afternoon, at least twice a week. They also report that tanning beds emitting 2–6 per cent UVB radiation will have a similar effect, though tanning may be inadvisable for other reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-VitD-NIH_105-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VitD-NIH-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Iron">Iron</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Blackstrapmolasses.JPG" title="File:Blackstrapmolasses.JPG">File:Blackstrapmolasses.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Molasses" title="Molasses">Molasses</a> is high in iron.</div></div></div>
<p>Vegetarian and vegan diets usually contain as much iron as animal-based diets, or more; vegan diets generally contain more iron than vegetarian ones because dairy products contain very little. There are concerns about the bioavailability of iron from plant foods, assumed by some researchers to be around 5–15 percent compared to 18 percent from a nonvegetarian diet.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iron_deficiency_anaemia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iron deficiency anaemia (page does not exist)">Iron deficiency anaemia</a> is found as often in nonvegetarians as in vegetarians, though studies have shown vegetarians' iron stores to be lower.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recommended_Dietary_Allowance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recommended Dietary Allowance (page does not exist)">RDA</a> for nonvegetarians is 11&#160;mg for 7–12 months, 7&#160;mg for 1–3 years, 10&#160;mg for 4–8 years, and 8&#160;mg for 9–13 years. The RDA then changes for men and women to 11&#160;mg for 14–18 years (men) and 15&#160;mg for 14–18 years (women), 8&#160;mg for 19–50 years (men) and 18&#160;mg for 19–50 years (women). It returns to 8&#160;mg for 51+ years (men and women).<sup id="cite_ref-iron-NIH_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iron-NIH-113">[113]</a></sup> Mangels writes that because of the lower bioavailability of iron from plant sources, the Food and Nutrition Board of the <a href="/wiki/National_Academy_of_Sciences" title="National Academy of Sciences">National Academy of Sciences</a> established a separate RDA for vegetarians and vegans of 14&#160;mg for vegetarian men and postmenopausal women, and 33&#160;mg for premenopausal women not using oral contraceptives.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> Supplements should be used only with caution after consulting a physician, because iron can accumulate within the body and cause damage to organs; this is particularly true of anyone suffering from <a href="/wiki/Hemochromatosis" title="Hemochromatosis" class="mw-redirect">hemochromatosis</a>, a relatively common condition that can remain undiagnosed. The daily tolerable upper intake level, according to the <a href="/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health" title="National Institutes of Health">National Institutes of Health</a>, is 40&#160;mg for 7 months to 13 years, and 45&#160;mg for 14+.<sup id="cite_ref-iron-NIH_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iron-NIH-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the Vegetarian Resource Group, high-iron foods suitable for vegans include black-strap molasses, lentils, tofu, quinoa, kidney beans and chickpeas.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> Tom Sanders, a nutritionist at King's College London, writes that iron absorption can be enhanced by eating a source of vitamin C along with a plant source of iron, and by avoiding coingesting anything that would inhibit absorption, such as <a href="/wiki/Tannin" title="Tannin">tannin</a> in tea.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Sources of vitamin C might be half a cup of cauliflower, or five fluid ounces of orange juice, consumed with a plant source of iron such as <a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">soybeans</a>, tofu, tempeh, or black beans.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> Some herbal teas and coffee can also inhibit iron absorption, as can spices that contain tannins (turmeric, coriander, chillies, and tamarind).<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Omega-3_fatty_acids">Omega-3 fatty acids</span></h4>
