<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:From_flax_to_linseed_oil..JPG" title="File:From flax to linseed oil..JPG">File:From flax to linseed oil..JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Flaxseed_oil" title="Flaxseed oil" class="mw-redirect">Flaxseed oil</a> contains a high level of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpha-linolenic_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alpha-linolenic acid (page does not exist)">alpha-linolenic acid</a>, an <a href="/wiki/Omega-3_fatty_acid" title="Omega-3 fatty acid">omega-3 fatty acid</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpha-linolenic_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alpha-linolenic acid (page does not exist)">Alpha-linolenic acid</a> (ALA), an omega-3 fatty acid, is found in leafy green vegetables and nuts, and in vegetable oils such as canola and flaxseed oil. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Adequate_Intake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Adequate Intake (page does not exist)">Adequate Intake</a> for ALA is 1.1–1.6 g/day.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Vegan Outreach suggests vegans take 1/4 teaspoon of flaxseed oil (also known as linseed oil) daily, and use oils containing low amounts of <a href="/wiki/Omega-6_fatty_acid" title="Omega-6 fatty acid">omega-6 fatty acids</a>, such as olive, canola, avocado or peanut oil.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Iodine">Iodine</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Iodine" title="Iodine">Iodine</a> supplementation may be necessary for vegans in countries where salt is not typically <a href="/w/index.php?title=Iodized_salt&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Iodized salt (page does not exist)">iodized</a>, where it is iodized at low levels, or where, as in Britain and Ireland, dairy products are relied upon for iodine delivery because of low levels in the soil.<sup id="cite_ref-Appleby1999_121-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Appleby1999-121">[121]</a></sup> Iodine can be obtained from most vegan multivitamins or from regular consumption of seaweeds, such as <a href="/wiki/Kelp" title="Kelp">kelp</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Recommended_Dietary_Allowance&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Recommended Dietary Allowance (page does not exist)">RDA</a> is 110 mcg (0–six months), 130 mcg (7–12 months), 90 mcg (1–8 years), 120 mcg (9–13 years), 150 mcg (14+). The RDA for pregnancy and lactation is 220 and 290 mcg respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Health_arguments">Health arguments</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
As of the 2000s, there was growing scientific consensus that a plant-based diet reduces the risk of a number of degenerative diseases, including coronary artery disease, diabetes, cancer, <a href="/wiki/Osteoporosis" title="Osteoporosis">osteoporosis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kidney_disease" title="Kidney disease" class="mw-redirect">kidney disease</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dementia" title="Dementia">dementia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-disease_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-disease-6">[6]</a></sup> According to nutritionist Winston Craig, writing in 2009, vegan diets tend to be higher in <a href="/wiki/Dietary_fibre" title="Dietary fibre" class="mw-redirect">dietary fibre</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magnesium" title="Magnesium">magnesium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Folic_acid" title="Folic acid">folic acid</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_C" title="Vitamin C">vitamin C</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vitamin_E" title="Vitamin E">vitamin E</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Human_iron_metabolism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Human iron metabolism (page does not exist)">iron</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phytochemical" title="Phytochemical">phytochemicals</a>, and lower in <a href="/wiki/Calorie" title="Calorie">calories</a>, <a href="/wiki/Saturated_fat" title="Saturated fat">saturated fat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cholesterol" title="Cholesterol">cholesterol</a>, long-chain <a href="/wiki/Omega-3_fatty_acids" title="Omega-3 fatty acids" class="mw-redirect">omega-3 fatty acids</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_D&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin D (page does not exist)">vitamin D</a>, <a href="/wiki/Calcium" title="Calcium">calcium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vitamin_B12&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vitamin B12 (page does not exist)">vitamin B12</a>. He wrote that vegans tend to be thinner, with lower serum cholesterol and lower blood pressure. Craig added that eliminating all animal products increases the risk of nutritional deficiencies; of particular concern are vitamins B12 and D, calcium and omega-3 fatty acids. He advised vegans to eat foods fortified with these nutrients or to take supplements, and warned that iron and zinc may also be problematic because of limited <a href="/wiki/Bioavailability" title="Bioavailability">bioavailability</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Craig_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Craig-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>The American Dietetic Association and Dietitians of Canada said in 2003 that properly planned vegan diets were nutritionally adequate for all stages of life, including pregnancy and lactation. People avoiding meat are reported to have lower <a href="/wiki/Body_mass_index" title="Body mass index">body mass index</a>; from this follows lower death rates from ischemic heart disease, lower blood cholesterol levels, lower blood pressure, and fewer incidences of type 2 diabetes, prostate and colon cancers. In 2013 the Australian National Health and Medical Research Council also recognized a well-planned vegan diet as a viable option for people of any age; they recommended that vegans eat B12-fortified foods or take supplements.<sup id="cite_ref-dietitians_7-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dietitians-7">[7]</a></sup> As of 2006 and 2011 respectively, the Swiss Federal Nutrition Commission and the German Society for Nutrition did not recommend a vegan diet, and cautioned against it for children, the pregnant and the elderly.<sup id="cite_ref-Switzerland-Germany_125-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Switzerland-Germany-125">[125]</a></sup>
</p><p>Between 1980 and 1984 the Oxford Vegetarian Study recruited 11,000 subjects (6,000 vegetarians and a control group of 5,000 non-vegetarians) and followed up after 12 years. The study indicated that vegans had lower total- and LDL-cholesterol concentrations than the meat-eaters, and that death rates were lower in the non-meat eaters. The authors wrote that mortality from <a href="/wiki/Ischemic_heart_disease" title="Ischemic heart disease" class="mw-redirect">ischemic heart disease</a> was positively associated with higher dietary cholesterol levels and the consumption of animal fat. They also wrote that the non-meat-eaters had half the risk of the meat eaters of requiring an emergency appendectomy, and that vegans in the UK may be prone to iodine deficiency.<sup id="cite_ref-Appleby1999_121-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Appleby1999-121">[121]</a></sup>
</p><p>A 1999 <a href="/wiki/Meta-analysis" title="Meta-analysis">meta-analysis</a> of five studies comparing mortality rates in Western countries found that mortality from ischemic heart disease was 26 percent lower in vegans than in regular meat-eaters. This was compared to 20 percent lower in occasional meat eaters, 34 percent lower in <a href="/wiki/Pescetarian" title="Pescetarian" class="mw-redirect">pescetarians</a> (those who ate fish but no other meat), and 34 percent lower in ovo-lacto vegetarians (those who ate no meat, but did consume animal milk and eggs). No significant difference in mortality from other causes was found between vegetarian/vegan and non-vegetarian diets.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> In 2010 a 15-year survey in the UK that examined the association between diet and age-related cataracts found that vegans had a 40 percent lower risk than the biggest meat eaters; it found a "progressive decrease in risk of cataract in high meat eaters to low meat eaters, fish eaters (participants who ate fish but not meat), vegetarians, and vegans."<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup>
</p><p>The American Dietetic Association indicated in 2003 that vegetarian diets may be more common among adolescents with eating disorders, but that the adoption of a vegetarian diet may serve to camouflage an existing disorder, rather than cause one.<sup id="cite_ref-dietitians_7-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dietitians-7">[7]</a></sup> Other studies supported that conclusion.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pregnancy.2C_babies_and_children">Pregnancy, babies and children</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
As of 2003 the American Dietetic Association and Dietitians of Canada considered well-planned vegan diets "appropriate for all stages of the life cycle, including during pregnancy, lactation, infancy, childhood and adolescence."<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> The Swiss Federal Nutrition Commission and the German Society for Nutrition cautioned against a vegan diet for pregnant women and children as of 2006 and 2011 respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-Switzerland-Germany_125-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Switzerland-Germany-125">[125]</a></sup> The American Dietetic Association added that a regular source of B12 is crucial for pregnant, lactating and breastfeeding women.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> According to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reed_Mangels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reed Mangels (page does not exist)">Reed Mangels</a>, maternal stores of B12 appear not to cross the <a href="/wiki/Placenta" title="Placenta">placenta</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> and researchers have reported cases of vitamin B12 deficiency in lactating vegetarian mothers that were linked to deficiencies and <a href="/wiki/Neurology" title="Neurology">neurological</a> disorders in their children.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Pregnant vegans may also need to take extra vitamin D, depending on their exposure to sunlight and whether they are eating fortified foods.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> Doctors may recommend iron supplements and folic acid for all pregnant women (vegan, vegetarian and non-vegetarian). A doctor or registered dietitian should be consulted about taking supplements during pregnancy.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the 2000s, newspapers reported several cases of <a href="/wiki/Malnutrition" title="Malnutrition">malnutrition</a> in children whose parents said they were vegan. A 12-year-old girl in Scotland who had eaten no meat or dairy since birth was found in 2008 to be suffering from <a href="/wiki/Rickets" title="Rickets">rickets</a> (caused by a lack of vitamin D), and had several fractures.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> In 2000, in London, a nine-month-old girl died after her vegan mother fed her a <a href="/wiki/Fruitarian" title="Fruitarian" class="mw-redirect">fruitarian</a> diet of raw fruit and nuts.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> In 2004, in Atlanta, a six-week-old boy died after his vegan parents appear to have fed him mostly apple juice and soy milk; the prosecution argued that the case was not about veganism, but that the child had simply not been fed.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Vegan_toiletries">Vegan toiletries</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:VeganSociety.jpg" title="File:VeganSociety.jpg">File:VeganSociety.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Products certified by the British <a href="/wiki/Vegan_Society" title="Vegan Society">Vegan Society</a> carry its sunflower symbol.</div></div></div>
<p>The British Vegan Society criteria for vegan certification are that the product contain no <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_product&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal product (page does not exist)">animal products</a>, and that neither the product nor its ingredients have been <a href="/wiki/Animal_testing" title="Animal testing">tested on animals</a> by the manufacturer, by others on behalf of the manufacturer, or by anyone over whom the manufacturer has control. The society's website contains a list of certified companies and products.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Beauty_Without_Cruelty&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Beauty Without Cruelty (page does not exist)">Beauty Without Cruelty</a> is well-known within the vegan community as a manufacturer of vegan toiletries and cosmetics. <a href="/wiki/Animal_Aid" title="Animal Aid">Animal Aid</a> in the UK sells vegan toiletries and other products online, as does Honesty Cosmetics.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup> Kiss My Face sells a range of vegan toiletries in the United States, Canada and the UK. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lush_(company)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lush (company) (page does not exist)">Lush</a> is based in a number of countries and sells products online; the company says that 83 percent of its products are vegan. Haut Minerals in Canada make a range of vegan products, including a vegan <a href="/w/index.php?title=BB_cream&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BB cream (page does not exist)">BB cream</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> In South Africa, Esse Organic Skincare is one of several companies certified by Beauty Without Cruelty. The Choose Cruelty Free website in Australia lists vegan products available there.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because animal ingredients are cheap, they are ubiquitous in toiletries. After animals are slaughtered for meat, the leftovers (bones, brains, eyes, spines and other parts) are put through the <a href="/wiki/Rendering_(animals)" title="Rendering (animals)">rendering</a> process, and some of that material, especially the <a href="/wiki/Animal_fat" title="Animal fat">fats</a>, ends up in toiletries and cosmetics.  Vegans often refer to <i>Animal Ingredients A to Z</i> (2004) to check which ingredients might be animal-derived. Common animal products in toiletries include <a href="/wiki/Tallow" title="Tallow">tallow</a> in soap, and <a href="/wiki/Glycerine" title="Glycerine" class="mw-redirect">glycerine</a> (derived from <a href="/wiki/Collagen" title="Collagen">collagen</a>), which is used as a lubricant and <a href="/wiki/Humectant" title="Humectant">humectant</a> in haircare products, moisturizers, shaving foam, soap and toothpaste; there is a plant-based form but the glycerine in most products is probably animal-based. <a href="/wiki/Lanolin" title="Lanolin">Lanolin</a>, from sheep's wool, is another common ingredient, found in lip balm and moisturizers, as is <a href="/wiki/Stearic_acid" title="Stearic acid">stearic acid</a>, used in face creams, shaving foam and shampoos; as with glycerine, there is a plant-based form of stearic acid, but most mainstream manufacturers use the animal-derived form. <a href="/wiki/Lactic_acid" title="Lactic acid">Lactic acid</a>, an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alpha-hydroxy_acid&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alpha-hydroxy acid (page does not exist)">alpha-hydroxy acid</a> derived from animal milk, is often found in moisturizers, as is <a href="/wiki/Allantoin" title="Allantoin">allantoin</a>, derived from the comfrey plant or cow's urine, and found in shampoos, moisturizers and toothpaste.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Philosophy:_ethical_and_environmental_perspectives">Philosophy: ethical and environmental perspectives</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethical_veganism">Ethical veganism</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Arguments">Arguments</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Carol_J._Adams_with_Snowball.jpg" title="File:Carol J. Adams with Snowball.jpg">File:Carol J. Adams with Snowball.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Feminist writer <a href="/wiki/Carol_J._Adams" title="Carol J. Adams">Carol J. Adams</a> calls animals the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Absent_referent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Absent referent (page does not exist)">absent referent</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Ethical veganism is based on opposition to <a href="/wiki/Speciesism" title="Speciesism">speciesism</a>, the assignment of different values to individuals on the basis of their species membership alone. <a href="/wiki/Carol_J._Adams" title="Carol J. Adams">Carol J. Adams</a>, the vegan-feminist writer, has used the concept of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Absent_referent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Absent referent (page does not exist)">absent referent</a> to describe the detachment between the consumer and the consumed:
</p>
<blockquote>Behind every meal of meat is an absence: the death of the animal whose place the meat takes. The 'absent referent' is that which separates the meat eater from the animal and the animal from the end product. The function of the absent referent is to keep our 'meat' separated from any idea that she or he was once an animal, to keep the 'moo' or 'cluck' or 'baa' away from the meat, to keep <i>something</i> from being seen as having been some<i>one</i>."<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup></blockquote>
<p>There is a division within animal rights theory between a rights-based or <a href="/wiki/Deontological_ethics" title="Deontological ethics">deontological approach</a> and a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_rights&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal rights (page does not exist)">utilitarian</a> one, which is reflected in the debate about the moral basis of veganism. <a href="/wiki/Tom_Regan" title="Tom Regan">Tom Regan</a>, professor emeritus of philosophy at North Carolina State University, is a rights theorist who argues that animals possess inherent value as "subjects-of-a-life" – because they have beliefs and desires, an emotional life, memory, and the ability to initiate action in pursuit of goals – and must therefore be viewed as ends in themselves, not as a means to an end.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> He argues that the right of subjects-of-a-life not to be harmed can be overridden only when outweighed by other valid moral principles, but that the reasons cited for eating animal products – pleasure, convenience and the economic interests of farmers – are not weighty enough to override the animals' moral rights.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gary_Francione.jpg" title="File:Gary Francione.jpg">File:Gary Francione.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://vimeo.com/23001319">Video</a> of law professor <a href="/wiki/Gary_Francione" title="Gary Francione" class="mw-redirect">Gary Francione</a> speaking about veganism, 2009</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Gary_L._Francione" title="Gary L. Francione">Gary L. Francione</a>, professor of law at Rutgers School of Law-Newark, is also a rights theorist. He argues that "all sentient beings should have at least one right – the right not to be treated as property," and that adopting veganism must be the unequivocal baseline for anyone who sees nonhuman animals as having intrinsic moral value:<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup>
</p>
<blockquote> We all believe it's wrong to inflict unnecessary suffering and death on animals. ... So now the next question becomes "what do we mean by necessity?" Well, whatever it means, whatever abstract meaning it has, if it has any meaning whatsoever, its minimal meaning has to be that it's wrong to inflict suffering and death on animals for reasons of pleasure, amusement or convenience – because if it's all right to inflict suffering and death on animals for reasons of pleasure, amusement or convenience, then you've got a loophole that's now so large you could drive a truck through it. So if the moral notion that we all accept, if that has any meaning, then it has got to be the case that we can't inflict suffering and death on animals for reasons of pleasure, amusement or convenience. Okay. Problem is 99.9999999 percent of our animal use can only be justified by reasons of pleasure, amusement or convenience. It's gotta go. If we mean what we say ... we have no choice. Veganism is the only rational, logical response ..."<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup></blockquote>
<p>He argues that the pursuit of improved conditions for animals, rather than the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abolitionism_(animal_rights)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abolitionism (animal rights) (page does not exist)">abolition of animal use</a>, is like campaigning for "conscientious rapists" who will rape their victims without beating them. The pursuit of animal welfare does not move us away from the paradigm of animals <i>qua</i> property, and serves only to make people feel comfortable about using them.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Debate_about_the_.22Paris_exemption.22">Debate about the "Paris exemption"</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Singer1.jpg" title="File:Singer1.jpg">File:Singer1.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Philosopher <a href="/wiki/Peter_Singer" title="Peter Singer">Peter Singer</a> writes that personal purity is not the issue.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Peter_Singer" title="Peter Singer">Peter Singer</a>, professor of bioethics at Princeton University, argues from a utilitarian perspective that there is no moral or logical justification for refusing to count animal suffering as a consequence when making ethical decisions, and that sentience is "the only defensible boundary of concern for the interests of others."<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> He argues that killing animals should be rejected unless necessary for survival.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> Unlike Francione, Singer is not concerned about what he calls trivial infractions of vegan principles. He supports what is known as the "Paris exemption": if you find yourself in a fine restaurant, allow yourself to eat what you want, and if you have no access to vegan food, go vegetarian.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup>
</p><p>Singer's support for the "Paris exemption" is reflected within the animal rights movement by the divide between the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Animal_protectionism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Animal protectionism (page does not exist)">protectionist</a> side (represented by Singer and <a href="/w/index.php?title=PETA&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="PETA (page does not exist)">PETA</a>), according to which incremental change can achieve reform, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abolitionism_(animal_rights)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abolitionism (animal rights) (page does not exist)">abolitionist</a> side (represented by Regan and Francione), according to which apparent  welfare reform serves only to persuade the public that animal use is morally unproblematic.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bruce_Friedrich" title="Bruce Friedrich">Bruce Friedrich</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Farm_Sanctuary&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Farm Sanctuary (page does not exist)">Farm Sanctuary</a>, a protectionist, argued in 2006 that strict adherence to veganism can become an obsession:
</p>
<blockquote>[W]e all know people whose reason for not going vegan is that they "can't" give up cheese or ice cream. ... Instead of encouraging them to stop eating all other animal products besides cheese or ice cream, we preach to them about the oppression of dairy cows. ... [W]e've preserved our personal purity, but we've hurt animals – and that's anti-vegan.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup></blockquote>
<p>Francione writes that this is similar to arguing that, because human rights abuses can never be eliminated, we should not safeguard human rights in situations we control. By failing to ask a server whether something contains animal products, in the interest of avoiding a fuss, he argues that we reinforce the idea that the moral rights of animals are a matter of convenience. He concludes from this that the protectionist position fails even on its own consequentialist terms.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_veganism">Environmental veganism</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Resources_and_the_environment">Resources and the environment</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Paul_Watson_(cropped).jpg" title="File:Paul Watson (cropped).jpg">File:Paul Watson (cropped).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Paul_Watson" title="Paul Watson">Paul Watson</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Sea_Shepherd_Conservation_Society" title="Sea Shepherd Conservation Society">Sea Shepherd Conservation Society</a> is a vegan for environmental reasons.<sup id="cite_ref-Shapiro2010_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shapiro2010-155">[155]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Environmental vegans focus on conservation rather than animal rights: they reject the use of animal products on the premise that practices such as farming – particularly <a href="/wiki/Factory_farming" title="Factory farming" class="mw-redirect">factory farming</a> – fishing, hunting and trapping are environmentally unsustainable.<sup id="cite_ref-environmental_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-environmental-2">[2]</a></sup> One example of an environmental vegan is <a href="/wiki/Paul_Watson" title="Paul Watson">Paul Watson</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Sea_Shepherd_Conservation_Society" title="Sea Shepherd Conservation Society">Sea Shepherd Conservation Society</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Marine_conservation" title="Marine conservation">marine conservation</a> direct-action group. He told the <i>Guardian</i> in 2010 that all Sea Shepherd ships are vegan for environmental reasons: "Forty percent of the fish caught from the oceans is fed to livestock – pigs and chickens are becoming major aquatic predators. The livestock industry is one of the greatest contributors to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Greenhouse_gas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Greenhouse gas (page does not exist)">greenhouse gas</a> emissions ever. The eating of meat is an ecological disaster ... We're promoting veganism not for animal-rights reasons but for environmental conservation reasons."<sup id="cite_ref-Shapiro2010_155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Shapiro2010-155">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>In November 2006, the United Nations <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Agriculture_Organization" title="Food and Agriculture Organization">Food and Agriculture Organization</a> released <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Livestock%27s_Long_Shadow&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Livestock's Long Shadow (page does not exist)">Livestock's Long Shadow</a></i>, a report that linked animal agriculture to environmental damage. It concluded that livestock farming (primarily of cows, chickens and pigs) has an impact on almost all aspects of the environment: air, land, soil, water, <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Climate_change" title="Climate change">climate change</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> It concluded that livestock account for 9 percent of total <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> emissions, 37 percent of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Methane&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Methane (page does not exist)">methane</a>, 65 percent of <a href="/wiki/Nitrous_oxide" title="Nitrous oxide">nitrous oxide</a>, and 68 percent of <a href="/wiki/Ammonia" title="Ammonia">ammonia</a>; livestock waste emits 30 million tonnes of ammonia a year, which the report said is involved in the production of <a href="/wiki/Acid_rain" title="Acid rain">acid rain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 2010 a report from the United Nations Environment Programme declared that a move toward a vegan diet is needed to save the world from hunger, fuel shortages and climate change. It said that agriculture, particularly the production of meat and dairy products, accounts for 19 percent of the world's greenhouse gas emissions, 38 percent of land use and 70 percent of freshwater consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p><p>Greenhouse gas emissions are not limited to animal husbandry. Plant agriculture such as rice cultivation can also cause environmental problems.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> A 2007 Cornell University study that simulated land use for various diets for New York State concluded that, although vegetarian diets used the smallest amount of land <i>per capita</i>, a low-fat diet that included some meat and dairy – less than <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of meat/eggs per day, significantly less than that consumed by the average American – could support slightly more people on the same available land than could be fed on some high-fat vegetarian diets, since animal food crops are grown on lower-quality land than are crops for human consumption.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Debate_about_animals_killed_in_crop_harvesting">Debate about animals killed in crop harvesting</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Gestcrate01.jpg" title="File:Gestcrate01.jpg">File:Gestcrate01.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Female pigs in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gestation_crate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gestation crate (page does not exist)">gestation crates</a>. Vegans see animal agriculture, particularly <a href="/wiki/Factory_farming" title="Factory farming" class="mw-redirect">factory farming</a>, as an infringement of the animals' rights and a threat to the environment.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Steven Davis, a professor of <a href="/wiki/Animal_science" title="Animal science">animal science</a> at Oregon State University, asked <a href="/wiki/Tom_Regan" title="Tom Regan">Tom Regan</a> in 2001 what the difference was between killing a field mouse while cultivating crops, and killing a pig for the same reason, namely so that human beings could eat. Regan responded with what Davis called the "Least Harm Principle," according to which we must choose the food products that, overall, cause the least harm to the least number of animals. Davis argued that a plant-based diet would kill more than one containing beef from grass-fed <a href="/wiki/Ruminant" title="Ruminant">ruminants</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Davis2001_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davis2001-162">[162]</a></sup>
</p><p>Andy Lamey, a philosopher at Monash University, calls this the "burger vegan" argument, namely that if human beings were to eat cows raised on a diet of grass, not grain, fewer animals would be killed overall, because the number of mice, rats, raccoons and other animals killed during the harvest outnumbers the deaths involved in raising cows for beef.<sup id="cite_ref-Lamey_163-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lamey-163">[163]</a></sup>
</p><p>Based on a study finding that wood mouse populations dropped from 25 to five per hectare after harvest (attributed to migration and mortality), Davis estimated that 10 animals per hectare are killed from crop farming every year. He argued that if all <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of cropland in the continental United States were used for a vegan diet, approximately 500 million animals would die each year. But if half the cropland were converted to ruminant pastureland, he estimated that only 900,000 animals would die each year – assuming people switched from the eight billion poultry killed each year to beef, lamb and dairy products. Therefore, he argued, according to the least-harm principle we should convert to a ruminant-based diet rather than a plant-based one.<sup id="cite_ref-Davis2001_162-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Davis2001-162">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:VeganRallyEvolve.jpg" title="File:VeganRallyEvolve.jpg">File:VeganRallyEvolve.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Vegans at the Melbourne "Walk against Warming" during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2009_United_Nations_Climate_Change_Conference&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference (page does not exist)">2009 United Nations Climate Change Conference</a></div></div></div>
<p>Davis's analysis was criticized in 2003 by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jason_Gaverick_Matheny&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jason Gaverick Matheny (page does not exist)">Gaverick Matheny</a> in the <i>Journal of Agricultural and Environmental Ethics</i>. Matheny argued that Davis had miscalculated the number of animal deaths, based his figures on land area rather than per consumer, and had confined his analysis to grass-fed ruminants, rather than factory-farmed animals. He wrote that Davis had also equated lives with lives worth living, focusing on numbers rather than including in his calculations the harm done to animals raised for food, which can involve pain from branding, dehorning and castration, a life of confinement, transport without food or water to a slaughterhouse, and a frightening death. Matheny argued that vegetarianism "likely allows a greater number of animals with lives worth living to exist."<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p>Andy Lamey further argued that Davis's calculation of harvest-related deaths was flawed based on two studies. One study included deaths from <a href="/wiki/Predation" title="Predation">predation</a>, which Lamey wrote are morally unobjectionable for Regan because they are not related to human action. The other study examined production of a nonstandard crop (sugarcane), which Lamey wrote has little relevance to deaths associated with typical crop production.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> Lamey also maintained, like Matheny, that accidental deaths are ethically distinct from intentional ones, and that if Davis includes accidental animal deaths in the moral cost of veganism, he must also include the accidental human deaths caused by his proposed diet, which, Lamey wrote, leaves "Davis, rather than Regan, with the less plausible argument."<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup>
</p>

</ul>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Reflist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Reflist (page does not exist)">Template:Reflist</a>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_reading">Further reading</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Refbegin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Refbegin (page does not exist)">Template:Refbegin</a>
</p>
<dl>
<dt>Books (vegan diet)
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Brendan_Brazier&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brendan Brazier (page does not exist)">Brazier, Brendan</a>. <i>Thrive Foods: 200 Plant-Based Recipes for Peak Health</i>, Da Capo Press, 2011.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chloe_Coscarelli&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chloe Coscarelli (page does not exist)">Coscarelli, Chloe</a>. <i>Chloe's Kitchen</i>. Simon and Schuster, 2012.
</li>
<li> Hobbs, Suzanne Havala. <i>Living Dairy-Free For Dummies</i>, John Wiley &amp; Sons, 2010.
</li>
<li> Jamieson, Alexandra. <i>Living Vegan For Dummies</i>, John Wiley &amp; Sons, 2009.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Scott_Jurek" title="Scott Jurek">Jurek, Scott</a> with Friedman, Scott. <i>Eat and Run: My Unlikely Journey to Ultramarathon Greatness</i>, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, 2012.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Reed_Mangels&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Reed Mangels (page does not exist)">Mangels, Reed</a>; Messina, Virginia; and Messina, Mark. <i>The Dietitian's Guide to Vegetarian Diets</i>, Jones &amp; Bartlett Learning, 2011.
</li>
<li> Mangels, Reed. <i>The Everything Vegan Pregnancy Book</i>, Adams Media, 2011.
</li>
<li> Norris, Jack. <i>Vegan for Life: Everything You Need to Know to Be Healthy and Fit on a Plant-Based Diet</i>,  Da Capo Lifelong Books, 2011.
</li>
<li> Schinner, Mikoyo. <i>Artisan Vegan Cheese</i>, Book Publishing Co., 2012.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gene_Stone&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gene Stone (page does not exist)">Stone, Gene</a> (ed.). <i>Forks Over Knives: The Plant-Based Way to Health</i>, The Experiment, 2011.
</li>
<li> Wasserman, Debra and Mangels, Reed (eds.). <i>Vegan Handbook</i>, Vegetarian Resource Group, 2010.
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Books (general)
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gordon_Conway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gordon Conway (page does not exist)">Conway, Gordon</a>. <i>One Billion Hungry: Can We Feed the World?</i>, Cornell University Press, 2012.
</li>
<li> Francis, Richard. <i>Fruitlands: The Alcott Family and their Search for Utopia</i>, Yale University Press, 2010.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kathy_Rudy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kathy Rudy (page does not exist)">Rudy, Kathy</a>. <i>Loving Animals: Toward a New Animal Advocacy</i>, University of Minnesota Press, 2011.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Safran_Foer" title="Jonathan Safran Foer">Safran Foer, Jonathan</a>. <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Eating_Animals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eating Animals (page does not exist)">Eating Animals</a></i>, Hamish Hamilton, 2010.
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Articles/lectures
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> American Dietetic Association. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://web.archive.org/web/20080729062427/http://www.eatright.org/cps/rde/xchg/ada/hs.xsl/governance_5105_ENU_HTML.htm">"A new food guide for North American vegetarians"</a>, 2003.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=T._Colin_Campbell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="T. Colin Campbell (page does not exist)">Campbell, T. Colin</a> and Rodriguez, Nancy. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10000872396390444184704577587174077811182.html">"Would We Be Healthier With a Vegan Diet?"</a>, <i>The Wall Street Journal</i>, 18 September 2012.
</li>
<li> Henning, Brian G. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.2979/ethicsenviro.16.2.63">"Standing in Livestock's ‘Long Shadow’: The Ethics of Eating Meat on a Small Planet"</a>, <i>Ethics and the Environment</i>, 16(2), Fall 2011, pp.&#160;63–93.
</li>
<li> Ibrahim, Darian M. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://scholarship.law.duke.edu/lcp/vol70/iss1/4/">"A Return to Descartes: Property, Profit, and the Corporate Ownership of Animals"</a>, <i>Law and Contemporary Problems</i>, 70(1), Animal Law and Policy, Winter 2007, pp.&#160;89–115 (also available <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.jstor.org/stable/27592166">here</a>).
</li>
<li> Jacobs, D.R. et al. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19297463">"Food, plant food, and vegetarian diets in the US dietary guidelines: conclusions of an expert panel"</a>, <i>The Amerian Journal of Clinical Nutrition</i>, 89(5), May 2009, pp.&#160;1549–1552 (<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/89/5/1549S.long">full text</a>).
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Klaper&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Klaper (page does not exist)">Klaper, Michael</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=52a3qrZKic4">"A Diet For All Reasons"</a>, lecture, 1993.
</li>
<li> Leneman, Leah. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/09612029700200144">"The awakened instinct: vegetarianism and the women's suffrage movement in Britain"</a>, <i>Women's History Review</i>, 6(2), 1997, pp.&#160;271–287.
</li>
<li> Mangels, Reed. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vrg.org/nutrition/veganpregnancy.htm">"Pregnancy and the Vegan Diet"</a>, Vegetarian Resource Group., 2006.
</li>
<li> Messina, M. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19072500">"Investigating the optimal soy protein and isoflavone intakes for women: a perspective"</a>, <i>Women's Health</i>, 4(4), July 2008, pp.&#160;337–356 (review article).
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tara_Parker-Pope&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tara Parker-Pope (page does not exist)">Parker-Pope, Tara</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/01/14/how-to-go-vegan/">"How to Go Vegan"</a>, <i>The New York Times</i>, 14 January 2013.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Michael_Pollan" title="Michael Pollan">Pollan, Michael</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2002/11/10/magazine/an-animal-s-place.html?src=pm">"An Animal's Place,"</a> <i>The New York Times</i> Magazine, 10 November 2002.
</li>
<li> Reynolds, Gretchen. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://well.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/20/can-athletes-perform-well-on-a-vegan-diet/">"Can Athletes Perform Well on a Vegan Diet?"</a>, <i>The New York Times</i>, 20 June 2012.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gary_Steiner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gary Steiner (page does not exist)">Steiner, Gary</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/22/opinion/22steiner.html">"Animal, Vegetable, Miserable"</a>, <i>The New York Times</i>, 21 November 2009.
</li>
<li> Walker, Ruth. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.scotsman.com/lifestyle/features/new-film-poses-tough-question-could-animal-based-foods-be-doing-us-more-harm-than-good-1-2735017">"New film poses tough question: Could animal-based foods be doing us more harm than good?"</a>, <i>The Scotsman</i>, 13 January 2013.
</li>
<li> Wildman, James. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://vimeo.com/16606816"><i>101 Reasons to Go Vegan</i></a>, The Institute for Humane Education, lecture, 2010.
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Films
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Earthlings_(film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Earthlings (film) (page does not exist)">Earthlings</a></i>, 2005.
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Food,_Inc.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Food, Inc. (page does not exist)">Food, Inc.</a></i> 2008.
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Forks_over_Knives&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Forks over Knives (page does not exist)">Forks over Knives</a></i>, 2011.
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Speciesism:_The_Movie&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Speciesism: The Movie (page does not exist)">Speciesism: The Movie</a></i>, 2012.
</li>
<li> <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Vegucated&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vegucated (page does not exist)">Vegucated</a></i>, 2011.
</li>
</ul>
<dl>
<dt>Early vegan/vegetarian texts
</dt>
</dl>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Anna_Kingsford" title="Anna Kingsford">Kingsford, Anna</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.anna-kingsford.com/english/Works_by_Anna_Kingsford_and_Maitland/Texts/02-OAKM-I-PWayDiettxt-web.htm"><i>The Perfect Way in Diet</i></a>, Kegan Paul, Trench &amp; Co., 1881.
</li>
<li> Riston, Joseph. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://books.google.com/books?id=Cn8EAAAAYAAJ&amp;printsec=frontcover"><i>An Essay on Abstinence from Animal Food, as a Moral Duty</i></a>, Wilks and Taylor, 1802.
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Henry_Stephens_Salt" title="Henry Stephens Salt">Salt, Henry Stephens</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ivu.org/history/europe19b/salt_a_plea_for_vegetarianism.pdf"><i>A Plea for Vegetarianism</i></a>, Vegetarian Society, 1886.
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Percy_Bysshe_Shelley&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Percy Bysshe Shelley (page does not exist)">Shelley, Percy Bysshe</a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/38727"><i>A Vindication of Natural Diet</i></a>, F. Pitman, 1884.
</li>
<li> Wheldon, Rupert H. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.gutenberg.org/ebooks/22829"><i>No Animal Food</i></a>, Health Culture Co., 1910 (first known vegan cookbook).
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Howard_Williams_(humanitarian)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Howard Williams (humanitarian) (page does not exist)">Williams, Howard</a>. <i>The Ethics of Diet</i>, Swan Sonnenschein &amp; Co., 1896.
</li>
</ul>

</li>

</li>

</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vegansociety.com/html/food/nutrition/">Vegan nutrition</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vegan_Society" title="Vegan Society">Vegan Society</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.veganvillage.co.uk/">Vegan Village</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.vegetarian.org.uk/">Viva!</a>, formerly the Vegetarian and Vegan Foundation
</li>
</ul>
